docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama flew to New Hampshire Tuesday to promote an overhaul of health care, as one of the fiercest policy debates in decades heated up.

headline.main: As Health Care Debate Rages, Obama Takes to the Stump
headline.print_headline: Obama and Lawmakers Fan Out to Promote Health Care Overhaul

byline.original: By JIM RUTENBERG and JACKIE CALMES

docs.lead_paragraph: Ross Douthat: Gail, this week I've been thinking back to the aftermath of last November's election, when quite a few conservatives comforted themselves with the notion that the United States was still a "center-right" nation, Barack Obama's victory notwithstanding. I wasn't one of them: I thought that you could find a steady leftward movement in polling data, running back to the late 1990s and driven by both economic and demographic trends, that might have made Obama's election possible even without the various disasters of the Bush era. Which is to say that I agreed with many of Obama's more left-wing supporters, who thought that he had a lot more room to govern like a liberal than many conservatives and centrists supposed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, protesters in several cities disrupted town-hall meetings on health care that were held by members of Congress. While Democrats claim that the protests were organized by conservative lobbying groups, Republicans say that the response was an unprovoked negative reaction to the Obama administration's proposals. The White House, which was caught a bit off guard by the reaction, has started a Web site to respond to some of the protesters' claims.

headline.main: What Happened to a Public Health Plan?

docs.abstract: Americans want better medical care, but fear change.

docs.lead_paragraph: The two top Democrats in the House, Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, have escalated the war of words over health care reform, calling some of the behavior of protesters at town hall events across the country "un-American."

headline.main: Pelosi and Hoyer Try to Shush the Shouters

docs.abstract: In an op-ed column, House leaders call town hall protesters "un-American."
